The **biodiversity patch** is a very large patch that adds several new [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") and contains other changes by Nicholas Webb. The current version is 1.2a for [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). For more information, visit the [biodiversity patch's home page](http://web.archive.org/web/20041209022619/http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~naw1/nh/nh_bio.html).

The biodiversity patch also incorporates three patches from other authors, including the [Heck² patch](/wiki/Heck%C2%B2_patch "Heck² patch"), the [photography patch](/wiki/Photography_patch "Photography patch") and a coin-flipping patch.

T. J. Brumfield was previously working on a port of this patch to *[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM")*; see the [slashem-devel archive](http://dir.gmane.org/gmane.games.roguelike.nethack.slashem.devel) for October 2007.

## Bestiary

### New monsters

The biodiversity patch slightly expands several [monster classes](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") that have very few members, or only a single member, in [vanilla](/wiki/Vanilla "Vanilla").

| Name                                                 | Symbol                                                                                | Origin                                                                                                                | Notes                                                                                                                                                           |
| ---------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |

| waterspout gargoyle                                  | g                                                                                     |                                                                                                                       | Has a spit attack that can [wet](/wiki/Wet "Wet") items                                                                                                         |
| brownie                                              | l                                                                                     | Celtic folklore                                                                                                       | Can improve [shoes](/wiki/Boots "Boots"), or tamper with the ones the player is wearing                                                                         |

| bandersnatch                                         | J                                                                                     | Lewis Carroll                                                                                                         | Digesting attack                                                                                                                                                |

### Changes to existing monsters

- The [steam vortex](/wiki/Steam_vortex "Steam vortex")'s [engulfing](/wiki/Engulf "Engulf") attack is now coded as **scalding** rather than [fire](/wiki/Fire "Fire") damage.
- [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome") (and [bats](/wiki/Bat "Bat")) use **echolocation** instead of [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
- [Quantum mechanics](/wiki/Quantum_mechanic "Quantum mechanic") (and clockwork automata) may be [named](/wiki/Call "Call") after historical figures.
- [Rope golems](/wiki/Rope_golem "Rope golem") drop [leashes](/wiki/Leash "Leash") when destroyed.
- [Straw golems](/wiki/Straw_golem "Straw golem") drop sheaves of hay when destroyed. They may also drop a [damaged](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") [fedora](/wiki/Fedora "Fedora"). (Clothing for a scarecrow?)
- [Iron golems](/wiki/Iron_golem "Iron golem") drop cogwheels and [large shields](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield") when destroyed, in addition to [iron chains](/wiki/Iron_chain "Iron chain"). Clockwork automata drop cogwheels and sprockets. These belong to the \_ [item class](/wiki/Item_class "Item class") (renamed 'useless item') and can be used as improvised weapons.
- [Guides](/wiki/Guide "Guide"), the [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") [quest guardians](/wiki/Quest_guardian "Quest guardian"), now offer services to players.

New names:

- The color and name of the [Knight quest](/wiki/Knight_quest "Knight quest") [nemesis](/wiki/Quest_nemesis "Quest nemesis") have been changed. [Ixoth](/wiki/Ixoth "Ixoth") is now the white-colored **Hwitwyrm**, an allusion to [Welsh folklore](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_dragon "wikipedia:White dragon"). The dragon's attacks and attributes remain the same.

- The [Chromatic Dragon](/wiki/Chromatic_Dragon "Chromatic Dragon") is renamed **Tiamat**.

- All regular dragons except the [gray dragon](/wiki/Gray_dragon "Gray dragon") have new names. (These are not randomized, as in [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack").)

  - [Silver dragon](/wiki/Silver_dragon "Silver dragon"): *Amphitere*
  - [Red dragon](/wiki/Red_dragon "Red dragon"): *Firedrake*
  - [White dragon](/wiki/White_dragon "White dragon"): *Lindworm*
  - [Orange dragon](/wiki/Orange_dragon "Orange dragon"): *Lung dragon*
  - [Black dragon](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon"): *Sirrush*
  - [Blue dragon](/wiki/Blue_dragon "Blue dragon"): *Leviathan*
  - [Green dragon](/wiki/Green_dragon "Green dragon"): *Wyvern*
  - [Yellow dragon](/wiki/Yellow_dragon "Yellow dragon"): *Guivre*

- The [large kobold](/wiki/Large_kobold "Large kobold") and [kobold lord](/wiki/Kobold_lord "Kobold lord") are renamed **kobold hewer** and **kobold chieftain**. The hewer can [tunnel](/wiki/Tunnel "Tunnel") if it has a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe").

- The [water nymph](/wiki/Water_nymph "Water nymph") and [wood nymph](/wiki/Wood_nymph "Wood nymph") are renamed **naiad** and **dryad**.

New appearances:

- [Tigers](/wiki/Tiger "Tiger") are now colored orange (f) instead of yellow (f), to distinguish them from the sphinx.

## Other changes

### Levels

- Many [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") home levels are now considered to be "outdoors", with "sky" overhead instead of a "ceiling". On these levels [dart traps](/wiki/Dart_trap "Dart trap") will be created instead of [falling rock traps](/wiki/Falling_rock_trap "Falling rock trap").
- The [Priest quest](/wiki/Priest_quest "Priest quest") branch may have a [different home level design](/wiki/Biodiversity_patch/Priest_quest "Biodiversity patch/Priest quest"), depending on which [pantheon](/wiki/Pantheon "Pantheon") the player was assigned at the beginning of the game.
- [Trees](/wiki/Tree "Tree") which produce specific types of fruit [comestibles](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible") have been added. There are also oak trees which produce acorns, and elven dogwoods (used to make elven wooden weapons).

### Items

- A golden wand has been added to the list of [randomized appearances](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") for wands, as an item that the gold bug can eat.
- Using a [wand of light](/wiki/Wand_of_light "Wand of light") to #[engrave](/wiki/Engrave "Engrave") produces glowing writing.
- [Amber](/wiki/Amber "Amber") may contain fossilized [xans](/wiki/Xan "Xan") or [spiders](/wiki/Spider "Spider"), which can be revived with [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh").

### Gameplay

- [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai") know the corpses of [sea monsters](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster") by their corresponding Japanese culinary names.
- [Orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") can saddle and [ride](/wiki/Ride "Ride") [wargs](/wiki/Warg "Warg"), instead of [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse").

## Variants

[UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") and some other variants incorporate part of this patch, most notably the [disintegrator](/wiki/Disintegrator "Disintegrator"), a much more dangerous cousin of the [rust monster](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster") and the [disenchanter](/wiki/Disenchanter "Disenchanter"). Some of the new names for generic dragons are also used in UnNetHack, but their breath types and resistances are randomized at the beginning of the game.

[dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") includes clockwork automata, both as a monster and [as a playable race](/wiki/Clockwork_Automaton_\(starting_race\) "Clockwork Automaton (starting race)"). Most of the monsters also appear in some form in [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

## See also

- [Biodiversity patch home page](http://web.archive.org/web/20041209022619/http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~naw1/nh/nh_bio.html)

Biodiversity patch
Author Nicholas Webb
Download link

The biodiversity patch is a very large patch that adds several new monsters and contains other changes by Nicholas Webb. The current version is 1.2a for NetHack 3.4.3. For more information, visit the biodiversity patch's home page.

The biodiversity patch also incorporates three patches from other authors, including the Heck² patch, the photography patch and a coin-flipping patch.

T. J. Brumfield was previously working on a port of this patch to SLASH'EM; see the slashem-devel archive for October 2007.

Bestiary

New monsters

The biodiversity patch slightly expands several monster classes that have very few members, or only a single member, in vanilla.

Name Symbol Origin Notes
sphinx f Egyptian/Greek mythology Challenges the player with riddles
waterspout gargoyle g Has a spit attack that can wet items
brownie l Celtic folklore Can improve shoes, or tamper with the ones the player is wearing
pooka l Celtic folklore Charms monsters (including your pets)
satyr n Greek mythology Steals items and charms monsters (including your pets)
labyrinth trapper t Hides in mazes
gold bug x Edgar Allan Poe (loosely) Steals (and eats) gold pieces and other golden items
will o' wisp y Widespread folklore Appears in swamps; its explosion attack causes confusion
bannik z Slavic folklore Attacks with scalding water
leshy z Slavic folklore Confusing gaze
bandersnatch J Lewis Carroll Digesting attack
jubjub bird J Lewis Carroll Intelligence draining gaze
clockwork automaton Q Six melee attacks
quark Q Particle physics Uses one of six random "flavor" attacks
disintegrator R This thread Passive disintegration attack
hunger hulk U Pun on umber hulk Makes its victims hungry
umbral hulk U Pun on umber hulk Blinds victims with its gaze
nosferatu V Uncertain origin Paralyzes its victims with fear
blemmye X Medieval folklore Legendary humanoid with its face on its torso, and no head
otyugh X Dungeons & Dragons Enjoys rotten food
poltergeist Folklore Throws projectiles
tortoise
alligator snapping turtle

Changes to existing monsters

  • The steam vortex's engulfing attack is now coded as scalding rather than fire damage.
  • Gnomes (and bats) use echolocation instead of infravision.
  • Quantum mechanics (and clockwork automata) may be named after historical figures.
  • Rope golems drop leashes when destroyed.
  • Straw golems drop sheaves of hay when destroyed. They may also drop a damaged fedora. (Clothing for a scarecrow?)
  • Iron golems drop cogwheels and large shields when destroyed, in addition to iron chains. Clockwork automata drop cogwheels and sprockets. These belong to the _ item class (renamed 'useless item') and can be used as improvised weapons.
  • Guides, the Tourist quest guardians, now offer services to players.

New names:

  • The color and name of the Knight quest nemesis have been changed. Ixoth is now the white-colored Hwitwyrm, an allusion to Welsh folklore. The dragon's attacks and attributes remain the same.
  • The Chromatic Dragon is renamed Tiamat.
  • All regular dragons except the gray dragon have new names. (These are not randomized, as in UnNetHack.)
    • Silver dragon: Amphitere
    • Red dragon: Firedrake
    • White dragon: Lindworm
    • Orange dragon: Lung dragon
    • Black dragon: Sirrush
    • Blue dragon: Leviathan
    • Green dragon: Wyvern
    • Yellow dragon: Guivre
  • The large kobold and kobold lord are renamed kobold hewer and kobold chieftain. The hewer can tunnel if it has a pick-axe.
  • The water nymph and wood nymph are renamed naiad and dryad.

New appearances:

  • Tigers are now colored orange (f) instead of yellow (f), to distinguish them from the sphinx.

Other changes

Levels

  • Many quest home levels are now considered to be "outdoors", with "sky" overhead instead of a "ceiling". On these levels dart traps will be created instead of falling rock traps.
  • The Priest quest branch may have a different home level design, depending on which pantheon the player was assigned at the beginning of the game.
  • Trees which produce specific types of fruit comestibles have been added. There are also oak trees which produce acorns, and elven dogwoods (used to make elven wooden weapons).

Items

  • A golden wand has been added to the list of randomized appearances for wands, as an item that the gold bug can eat.
  • Using a wand of light to #engrave produces glowing writing.
  • Amber may contain fossilized xans or spiders, which can be revived with stone to flesh.

Gameplay

  • Samurai know the corpses of sea monsters by their corresponding Japanese culinary names.
  • Orcs can saddle and ride wargs, instead of horses.

Variants

UnNetHack and some other variants incorporate part of this patch, most notably the disintegrator, a much more dangerous cousin of the rust monster and the disenchanter. Some of the new names for generic dragons are also used in UnNetHack, but their breath types and resistances are randomized at the beginning of the game.

dNetHack includes clockwork automata, both as a monster and as a playable race. Most of the monsters also appear in some form in SlashTHEM.
